title: 108_s538
content: The Act titled "Lifespan Respite Care Act of 2003" amends the Public Health Service Act by adding a new section on Lifespan Respite Care with specific findings and purposes outlined. Congress finds that millions of individuals in the United States provide care for family members with chronic illnesses or disabilities, including children with special needs and elders with multiple disabling conditions. Approximately 600,000 Americans die at home each year, many relying on extensive family caregiving. 42 percent of individuals needing daily assistance in the US are under 65. Family caregivers face emotional, physical, and financial hardships, with services costing $200 billion annually if replaced with paid workers. 75 percent of family caregivers are women. The text chunk discusses the challenges faced by family caregivers in accessing respite care programs. These programs are insufficient and primarily cater to lower-income populations and the elderly, leaving many caregivers without adequate support. The goal is to encourage the establishment of state and local respite care programs, improve information dissemination, and provide better services to family caregivers. The text chunk focuses on promoting innovative approaches to delivering respite care, supporting research on effective respite care services, and disseminating information on respite care delivery and caregiver training programs. The curr_chunk focuses on recruitment and training for workers and volunteers, as well as training programs for family caregivers to help them make informed decisions about respite care services. The curr_chunk focuses on defining key terms related to recruitment, training, and respite care services for workers, volunteers, and family caregivers. The curr_chunk defines the term 'eligible recipient' as a State agency, public entity, nonprofit organization, political subdivision with a population of at least 3,000,000 individuals, or a recognized State respite coordinating agency with specific capabilities. The curr_chunk defines terms related to individuals with special needs, including adults and children requiring care or supervision for basic needs or to prevent injury. It also mentions the importance of involving family members and caregivers in the care process. The curr_chunk defines terms related to family caregivers and respite care for individuals with special needs, providing temporary relief and support for those caring for children or adults with special needs. Lifespan respite care is a coordinated system of accessible services for family caregivers. The curr_chunk discusses Lifespan Respite Care Grants and Cooperative Agreements. The section aims to expand respite care services for family caregivers, improve dissemination and coordination, and enhance access and quality of services to reduce caregiver strain. The Secretary is authorized to award grants to eligible recipients for this purpose, working in collaboration with relevant programs. The Administration on Developmental Disabilities, Maternal and Child Health Bureau, and Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration collaborate to coordinate respite care services for family caregivers of individuals with special needs. Eligible recipients must submit an application detailing their understanding of respite care and family caregiver issues. The Administration on Developmental Disabilities, Maternal and Child Health Bureau, and Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration collaborate to coordinate respite care services for family caregivers of individuals with special needs. Eligible recipients must submit an application detailing their understanding of respite care and family caregiver issues, including capacity for involvement of family members and collaboration with other agencies. Description of the population of family caregivers, their respite care needs, and existing services is required. The curr_chunk discusses existing respite care services for family caregivers, methods to coordinate respite care information, and how respite care information dissemination and coordination will be provided. The curr_chunk outlines the plan for collaboration and coordination of respite care activities with other related services, including public or private entities and area agencies on aging. It also highlights the involvement of the population, including family caregivers and care recipients, in the planning and implementation of respite care activities. Additionally, it mentions maximizing the use of grant or cooperative agreement funds for respite care services. The curr_chunk emphasizes the importance of utilizing various resources such as Federal, State, and local funds, programs, and personnel for respite care services. It also addresses the availability of respite care services for family caregivers, criteria for eligibility, and ensuring quality and safety standards. The curr_chunk discusses monitoring the quality and safety of respite care services, screening workers and volunteers, evaluating results of respite care activities, and maintaining confidentiality of care recipient and family caregiver records. The Secretary establishes a panel to review applications for grants or cooperative agreements, meeting as needed to evaluate and make recommendations for approval. Grants are awarded based on the panel's recommendations, with priority given to approved applications. When awarding grants or cooperative agreements, the Secretary prioritizes applicants likely to enhance lifespan respite care statewide. Recipients must use funds for developing respite care at state and local levels and evaluating its effectiveness. The recipient awarded a grant or cooperative agreement can use funds for respite care services, training programs for caregivers, and evaluations of the effectiveness of activities funded. The Secretary may award grants or cooperative agreements for up to 5 years and may renew them. Funds must supplement, not replace, other available funds for respite care services. Authorization of appropriations for respite care services includes $90,500,000 for fiscal year 2004 and necessary sums for fiscal years 2005 through 2008. The National Lifespan Respite Resource Center will be established through a grant or cooperative agreement to maintain a national database, provide training and technical assistance, and offer information on lifespan respite care. $500,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2004 to 2008. The Senate passed the bill on April 10, 2003.
